questions.question: For U.S. tax purposes, a U.S. person includes:

options.A: Only U.S. citizens residing in the U.S.
options.B: U.S. citizens, resident aliens, and domestic corporations
options.C: Only individuals born in the U.S.
options.D: Anyone conducting business in the U.S.

questions.explanation: U.S. persons include U.S. citizens (regardless of where they live), resident aliens, domestic corporations, domestic partnerships, and certain estates and trusts. U.S. persons are taxed on worldwide income and must report foreign accounts and assets.
questions.tip: U.S. persons: citizens, resident aliens, domestic entities. Taxed on worldwide income.

questions.question: An alien individual meets the substantial presence test if present in the U.S. for:

options.A: 183 days during the current year only
options.B: 31+ days in current year AND a weighted 183+ day total over 3 years

questions.explanation: The substantial presence test requires: (1) at least 31 days in the current year, AND (2) a weighted total of 183+ days over 3 years (current year days + 1/3 of prior year + 1/6 of second prior year). Meeting this test makes the alien a resident for tax purposes.
questions.tip: Substantial presence: 31 days current year + weighted 183 over 3 years. Formula: 100% + 1/3 + 1/6.

questions.question: The foreign tax credit is designed to:

options.B: Prevent double taxation of the same income by the U.S. and a foreign country
options.C: Reduce U.S. tax rates for exporters

questions.explanation: The foreign tax credit prevents double taxation by allowing U.S. taxpayers to credit foreign income taxes paid against their U.S. tax liability. This ensures income earned abroad and taxed by a foreign country isn't taxed again in full by the U.S.
questions.tip: FTC: credit for foreign taxes paid on foreign-source income. Prevents same income being taxed twice.

questions.question: Compensation for personal services is sourced based on:

options.B: Where the services are performed

questions.explanation: Personal service income is sourced where the services are performed, regardless of the employer's location, payment location, or employee's residence. Services performed in the U.S. generate U.S.-source income; services abroad generate foreign-source income.
questions.tip: Personal services: where performed. Interest: residence of payer. Dividends: domestic vs. foreign corp.

questions.question: A U.S. person must file FinCEN Form 114 (FBAR) if aggregate foreign accounts exceed:

options.B: $10,000 at any time during the year
options.C: $50,000 on the last day of the year

questions.explanation: FBAR filing is required when the aggregate value of all foreign financial accounts exceeds $10,000 at any time during the calendar year. This is a Bank Secrecy Act requirement filed with FinCEN (Treasury), not the IRS, by April 15 (auto-extended to October 15).
questions.tip: FBAR: $10K aggregate at any time. File with FinCEN, not IRS. Due April 15 (auto-extension to Oct 15).

questions.question: Dividends paid by a U.S. domestic corporation are generally:

options.B: U.S.-source income

questions.explanation: Dividends from domestic corporations are U.S.-source income. Dividends from foreign corporations are generally foreign-source, except when a certain percentage of the foreign corporation's income is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business.
questions.tip: Dividend source: domestic corp = U.S. source. Foreign corp = foreign source (with exceptions).

questions.question: The foreign tax credit is limited to:

options.A: Foreign taxes paid regardless of U.S. tax liability
options.B: U.S. tax on foreign-source income (preventing offset of U.S. tax on U.S.-source income)

questions.explanation: The FTC limitation prevents using foreign taxes to offset U.S. tax on U.S.-source income. The limit = (Pre-credit U.S. tax) × (Foreign-source taxable income / Worldwide taxable income). Excess credits carry back 1 year and forward 10 years.
questions.tip: FTC limit = US tax × (foreign income / worldwide income). Can't use FTC to offset tax on US-source income.

questions.question: A controlled foreign corporation (CFC) exists when U.S. shareholders own:

options.A: Any shares of a foreign corporation
options.B: More than 50% of vote or value on any day of the year

questions.explanation: A CFC is a foreign corporation where U.S. shareholders (each owning 10% or more) together own more than 50% of the total combined voting power or value on any day during the tax year. CFC status triggers current U.S. taxation of certain undistributed income.
questions.tip: CFC: U.S. shareholders (10%+) own >50% vote or value. Triggers Subpart F and GILTI inclusions.

questions.question: Subpart F income includes:

options.A: All income of a controlled foreign corporation
options.B: Passive income and certain related-party transactions

questions.explanation: Subpart F income includes foreign personal holding company income (passive income like dividends, interest, rents, royalties), foreign base company sales and services income (related-party transactions), and insurance income. It's taxed currently to U.S. shareholders even if not distributed.
questions.tip: Subpart F: passive income + related-party sales/services. Taxed currently, not when distributed.

questions.question: GILTI (Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income) is:

options.B: CFC income exceeding a 10% return on tangible assets
options.C: Only income from tax haven jurisdictions

questions.explanation: GILTI is a CFC's tested income exceeding a deemed return (10% of qualified business asset investment—QBAI). It's designed to tax 'excess' returns presumed attributable to intangibles. Corporate shareholders receive a 50% deduction, resulting in an effective rate of about 10.5%.
questions.tip: GILTI: CFC income - 10% of tangible assets (QBAI). 50% deduction for C corps. Taxed currently.

questions.question: Interest income is generally sourced based on:

options.B: The residence of the payer

questions.explanation: Interest is sourced based on the residence (or in the case of corporations, country of incorporation) of the payer. Interest paid by a U.S. resident or domestic corporation is U.S.-source. Interest from foreign obligors is foreign-source.
questions.tip: Interest source: payer's residence. Royalties: where IP is used. Rent: property location.

questions.question: U.S.-source FDAP income paid to nonresident aliens is generally subject to withholding at:
questions.explanation: Fixed, Determinable, Annual, Periodic (FDAP) income paid to nonresidents is subject to 30% withholding. FDAP includes interest, dividends, rents, royalties, and some compensation. Tax treaties may reduce this rate. The withholding is on gross income with no deductions.
questions.tip: FDAP: 30% withholding on gross (no deductions). Treaties may reduce. ECI = regular rates with deductions.

questions.question: Effectively connected income (ECI) of a nonresident alien is:

options.B: Subject to 30% withholding
options.C: Taxed at graduated rates with allowable deductions
options.D: Only taxed if remitted to the U.S.

questions.explanation: ECI (income connected to a U.S. trade or business) is taxed at graduated rates, the same as U.S. persons, with allowable deductions. This differs from FDAP income, which is subject to flat 30% withholding on gross income. Nonresidents pay tax only on U.S.-source income.
questions.tip: ECI: U.S. trade or business income, regular tax with deductions. FDAP: passive income, 30% gross.

questions.question: Tax treaties typically:

options.A: Increase the tax burden on foreign investment
options.B: Reduce withholding rates and prevent double taxation

questions.explanation: Tax treaties reduce withholding rates on cross-border payments (dividends, interest, royalties), define when business profits can be taxed, provide tie-breaker rules for dual residents, and include mechanisms to prevent double taxation. Each treaty is separately negotiated with different terms.
questions.tip: Treaties: reduce rates, allocate taxing rights, prevent double taxation. Must claim treaty benefits on return.

questions.question: Form 5471 is required to report:

options.B: Ownership interests in certain foreign corporations

questions.explanation: Form 5471 is required for U.S. persons who are officers, directors, or shareholders of certain foreign corporations. It reports ownership, income, and transactions with the foreign corporation. Substantial penalties apply for failure to file (up to $10,000 per year per entity).
questions.tip: Form 5471: foreign corporations. Form 8865: foreign partnerships. FBAR: foreign bank accounts.

questions.question: Under Section 482, transactions between related parties must be priced at:

options.B: Arm's length prices (as if between unrelated parties)
options.C: Fair market value as determined by the IRS

questions.explanation: Section 482 requires that intercompany transactions be priced as if conducted between unrelated parties at arm's length. This prevents income shifting between jurisdictions through artificial pricing. Methods include comparable uncontrolled price, cost plus, and resale price.
questions.tip: Transfer pricing: arm's length = price unrelated parties would use. Prevents income shifting to low-tax jurisdictions.

questions.question: Foreign tax credits are calculated separately for different 'baskets' including:

options.B: Passive category income and general category income

questions.explanation: Foreign tax credits are calculated in separate baskets to prevent cross-crediting. The main baskets are: passive category income (dividends, interest, rents, royalties) and general category income (active business income). High-taxed income can be recharacterized.
questions.tip: FTC baskets: passive and general. Prevents using high foreign taxes on passive income to offset low-taxed active income.

questions.question: Form 8938 (FATCA) is required when specified foreign financial assets exceed:

options.B: $50,000 on last day or $75,000 at any time (higher for joint filers/foreign residents)

questions.explanation: Form 8938 reports specified foreign financial assets. Thresholds vary: $50,000 on last day or $75,000 at any time for single filers living in the U.S. (double for MFJ, higher for foreign residents). This is separate from FBAR and filed with the tax return.
questions.tip: Form 8938 (FATCA): higher thresholds than FBAR. Filed with return. FBAR filed separately with FinCEN.

questions.question: Income from the sale of inventory is generally sourced based on:

options.B: Where title passes

questions.explanation: Income from sales of purchased inventory is sourced where title passes. If inventory is produced and sold, income is allocated between production activities (where performed) and sales activities (title passage). Title passage can be by contract or default rules.
questions.tip: Inventory: title passage location. Produced inventory: split between production and sales source.

questions.question: Under the green card test, an alien is a U.S. resident for tax purposes:

options.B: At any time they are a lawful permanent resident
options.C: Only if they apply for U.S. citizenship
options.D: After substantial presence in the U.S.

questions.explanation: An individual with a green card (lawful permanent resident status) is treated as a U.S. resident for tax purposes from the first day they are present in the U.S. as an LPR. Status continues until officially relinquished or administratively/judicially determined to be abandoned.
questions.tip: Green card = resident from first day present as LPR. Continues until formally surrendered or revoked.

questions.question: Section 367 generally requires gain recognition on:

options.B: Transfers of appreciated property to foreign corporations in otherwise tax-free exchanges

questions.explanation: Section 367 is an 'outbound toll charge' requiring gain recognition when appreciated property is transferred to a foreign corporation in transactions that would otherwise be tax-free (like Section 351 contributions or reorganizations). This prevents taxpayers from moving appreciated assets offshore tax-free.
questions.tip: Section 367: gain recognized on outbound transfers. Can't use 351/reorganization to avoid tax on transfer to foreign corp.

questions.question: A passive foreign investment company (PFIC) is a foreign corporation where:

options.B: 75% or more of income is passive OR 50% or more of assets produce passive income

questions.explanation: A PFIC exists when a foreign corporation meets either: (1) 75% of gross income is passive (income test), or (2) 50% of assets produce or are held to produce passive income (asset test). PFIC shareholders face harsh tax treatment including interest charges on deferred gains.
questions.tip: PFIC: 75% income or 50% assets passive. Unlike CFC, no ownership threshold. Harsh tax treatment.

questions.question: The branch profits tax is imposed on foreign corporations to:

options.A: Encourage foreign investment in the U.S.
options.B: Equalize tax treatment between U.S. branches and U.S. subsidiaries

questions.explanation: The branch profits tax (30%, reduced by treaty) applies to a foreign corporation's effectively connected earnings that are repatriated or deemed repatriated. It mimics the withholding tax on dividends that would apply if the branch were a U.S. subsidiary paying dividends to its foreign parent.
questions.tip: Branch profits tax: 30% on ECI 'dividend equivalent.' Equalizes treatment with subsidiary + dividend structure.

questions.question: Corporate shareholders receiving dividends from a 10%-or-more-owned foreign corporation:

options.A: Cannot claim any foreign tax credit
options.B: May claim a deemed-paid credit for the foreign taxes paid by the corporation
options.C: Must include the dividend in GILTI
options.D: Are taxed at capital gains rates

questions.explanation: Corporate shareholders owning 10% or more can claim a deemed-paid (indirect) foreign tax credit for foreign taxes paid by the foreign corporation on earnings from which dividends are paid. This gives credit for underlying corporate taxes, not just withholding taxes.
questions.tip: Deemed paid credit: corporate shareholder, 10%+ ownership. Credit for corp-level foreign taxes, not just withholding.

questions.question: The Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax (BEAT) applies to:

options.B: Large corporations with significant base erosion payments to foreign related parties

questions.explanation: BEAT is a minimum tax on large corporations (average gross receipts of $500M+ over 3 years) with significant base erosion payments (deductible payments to foreign related parties exceeding 3% of deductions). It prevents excessive profit shifting through related-party payments.
questions.tip: BEAT: large corps, significant foreign related-party payments. Minimum tax to prevent profit stripping.

questions.question: The FDII deduction encourages U.S. corporations to:

options.B: Export goods and services by providing a reduced tax rate on foreign-derived income

questions.explanation: FDII provides a 37.5% deduction for income derived from sales to foreign persons and services provided to foreign persons, resulting in an effective tax rate of about 13.125%. This incentivizes keeping operations and IP in the U.S. while exporting.
questions.tip: FDII: export incentive. 37.5% deduction for foreign-derived income. Encourages U.S.-based production for export.

questions.question: Under Section 956, a U.S. shareholder of a CFC may be taxed when the CFC:

options.B: Invests in U.S. property (treating investment as deemed dividend)

questions.explanation: Section 956 treats a CFC's investment in U.S. property (loans to U.S. shareholders, U.S. stock, U.S. real estate) as a deemed distribution to U.S. shareholders. This prevents using CFC funds in the U.S. without triggering a taxable dividend. TCJA reduced its impact for C corps.
questions.tip: Section 956: CFC investment in U.S. property = deemed dividend. Prevents repatriation avoidance.

questions.question: A 'covered expatriate' who renounces U.S. citizenship is subject to:

options.B: Mark-to-market exit tax on unrealized gains
options.D: Future withholding on all U.S. income

questions.explanation: Covered expatriates (meeting asset, tax, or compliance thresholds) are treated as having sold all worldwide assets for FMV on the day before expatriation. Gains exceeding an exclusion amount (~$886,000 in 2024) are taxed. Special rules apply to deferred compensation and trusts.
questions.tip: Exit tax: mark-to-market on expatriation. Covered = high net worth, high tax, or non-compliant.

questions.question: Form 3520 is required to report:

options.B: Transactions with foreign trusts and receipt of large foreign gifts

questions.explanation: Form 3520 reports transactions with foreign trusts (transfers, distributions, beneficial interests) and receipt of gifts or bequests from foreign persons exceeding $100,000. Failure to file can result in penalties of 35% of the trust's gross value or 5-25% of gifts.
questions.tip: Form 3520: foreign trusts + large foreign gifts ($100K+). Harsh penalties for non-filing.

questions.question: When an individual is a tax resident of both the U.S. and a treaty country, the treaty typically determines residency based on:

options.B: Permanent home, center of vital interests, habitual abode, and nationality (in order)
options.C: Whichever country taxes at a higher rate

questions.explanation: Treaty tie-breakers resolve dual residency in this order: (1) permanent home, (2) center of vital interests (personal and economic ties), (3) habitual abode, (4) nationality. If still unresolved, competent authorities of both countries negotiate. The result affects which country has primary taxing rights.
questions.tip: Treaty tie-breaker: home → vital interests → habitual abode → nationality. Resolves which country treats person as resident.

questions.question: Large multinational enterprises must prepare country-by-country reports that include:

options.B: Revenue, profit, tax, employees, and assets by country for each jurisdiction

questions.explanation: Country-by-country reporting (Form 8975) requires MNEs with $850M+ in annual revenue to report revenues, profits, taxes paid, employees, and assets for each tax jurisdiction. This provides transparency for tax authorities to assess transfer pricing risks.
questions.tip: CbC reporting: $850M+ MNEs. Report key data by jurisdiction. Filed with master and local file documentation.

questions.question: A taxpayer may elect to deduct rather than credit foreign taxes when:

options.B: The election is made annually and applies to all foreign taxes for that year
options.C: Only for taxes on passive income

questions.explanation: Taxpayers may elect to deduct foreign taxes instead of claiming the credit. The election applies to all foreign taxes for the year (can't mix credit and deduction). Deduction is beneficial when in an excess credit position or when simplicity is preferred. Credits are usually more valuable.
questions.tip: Deduction vs. credit: election applies to all foreign taxes. Credit usually better (reduces tax dollar-for-dollar).

questions.question: Without a QEF or mark-to-market election, PFIC shareholders face:

options.B: Interest charges on gains as if taxes were deferred since acquisition

questions.explanation: Default PFIC rules impose tax at the highest ordinary rates on 'excess distributions' and gains, plus an interest charge as if the income had been earned pro rata over the holding period and taxes deferred. QEF or MTM elections avoid this harsh treatment but require annual income inclusion.
questions.tip: PFIC default: ordinary rates + interest charge. QEF election: current income inclusion. MTM: annual FMV adjustment.

questions.question: Section 7874 anti-inversion rules treat a foreign corporation as domestic when:

options.B: Former U.S. shareholders own 80%+ after acquisition of a U.S. corporation and the group lacks substantial business in the foreign country
options.C: It is publicly traded in the U.S.

questions.explanation: Section 7874 treats a foreign acquirer as a domestic corporation (full tax consequences) if former U.S. shareholders own 80%+ after an inversion transaction and the group lacks substantial business activities in the foreign country. At 60-79%, the U.S. corporation is limited in using tax attributes.
questions.tip: Section 7874: 80%+ = treated as domestic. 60-79% = attribute limitations. Substantial business activities test applies.

questions.question: The GILTI high-tax exclusion allows taxpayers to exclude income that:

options.B: Is subject to a foreign effective tax rate exceeding 90% of the U.S. corporate rate

questions.explanation: The high-tax exclusion allows elective exclusion of CFC tested income (from GILTI) that is subject to a foreign effective tax rate exceeding 90% of the U.S. corporate rate (currently 18.9%). This recognizes that highly-taxed foreign income doesn't represent the 'low-taxed' income GILTI targets.
questions.tip: GILTI high-tax exclusion: foreign rate > 90% of U.S. rate (>18.9%). Elective, can apply to some CFCs.
